text:
16. Before assigning an interim grade, a teacher may employ a grading scale different from the 10-point scale for grading assessment elements. However, in this case, details regarding the relevant grading procedure and system must be provided in the course syllabus.
If assessment elements are evaluated using a grading scale other than the 10-point scale, the rules for converting interim grades to the 10-point grading scale must be outlined in the corresponding course syllabus.
A pass/fail assessment system, without differentiation in terms of the 10-point grading scale, can be implemented for Physical Education courses, project-based activities with a credit load equal to or below 3 (three) credits, supervisor's seminars under Master’s programmes, and as part of mandatory independent examinations. Details about the grading system applied should be documented in the syllabi of the relevant courses.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text: 17. Grades for interim assessments will be calculated using a formula (rule) that considers all grades received for all assessment elements. The formula for calculating grades assigned for an interim assessment must be specified in the relevant course syllabus. When assigning grades for interim assessments, the same rules shall apply to any attempt to pass the given assessment element.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text: 18. Assessment elements that are ineligible for or not subject to retakes, e.g., typically those that cannot be repeated such as class attendance, seminar participation, or performing a specific task, must be identified in the course syllabus along with the formula (rule) for calculating interim assessment grades. The content of such assessment elements is not included in the CMMs used for retakes. The total weighted sum of assessment elements ineligible for or not subject to retakes cannot exceed 30% in the interim assessment grade.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text: 19. If the formula (rule) for calculating an interim assessment grade uses the weighted sum of grades received for assessment elements with a total weight of 1 (one), no single grade for assessment elements may account for more than 70% in the interim assessment grade.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text: 20. The formula (rules) for calculating interim grades may be presented as a non-linear expression, incorporating various selection elements (such as minimum or maximum values from among different point values, selection from several grades based on specific conditions, etc.), or may involve ranking students' assessment results based on certain rules, or follow any other pattern specified in the given course syllabus.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text: 21. The final grade for a course comprising multiple interim assessments may be influenced by grades from previous interim assessments, in addition to grades received for assessment elements during the latest period of study under the course. The procedure for calculating final grades must be detailed in the respective course syllabus.
heading_path: II. Grading System and Grade Calculation

text:
22. Assessments may be conducted:
22.1. during contact hours, under the supervision of teachers, in accordance with the established timetable (synchronous assessment elements);

22. Assessments may be conducted:
22.2. during independent study hours, without the supervision of a teacher or teaching assistant, with subsequent grading by a teacher or teaching assistant (asynchronous assessment elements);

22. Assessments may be conducted:
22.3. by utilising remote technologies, such as EIOS tools and proctoring technologies, both during contact hours with a teacher (e.g., at webinars, video conferences, etc.) and during self-study periods, with subsequent auto-grading of results (blended assessment elements).

23. Assessment elements may include homework, in-class assignments, independent projects, reports, essays, colloquiums, lab assignments, term papers, examinations, and other formats, as selected by the lead teacher responsible for a given course and duly specified in the syllabus.
24. Synchronous and blended assessment elements, which require a teacher’s presence, cannot be scheduled outside of contact hours on campus at the University.

25. Teachers are required to register assessment grades in ongoing assessment records. Such records may be kept in electronic media, such as the EIOS, provided they are easily accessible to students. The head of the respective subdivision will determine the format of ongoing assessment records (e.g., provisional or final forms) and any specific template requirements. If the subdivision head provides no specific recommendations, the lead teacher will recommend that all teachers engaged in implementing the given course use a specific assessment record template available in the EIOS, or that they use a free format set of assessment form parameters. Upon completion of a course, the teacher must upload the assessment record to the course webpage in the EIOS (they have the option of publishing a link to a cloud storage file, or a file with the assessment record, or a photograph of the hard copy of the assessment record, or of filling in the grade register in the EIOS).

26. If a course includes an interim assessment to be taken by students during the current study period, the last assessment element held during the examination period or within 10 (ten) calendar days before the examination period is hereinafter referred to as an “examination.”

27. Examinations may be scheduled earlier than 10 (ten) days before the examination period for individual students (at a student’s request) or for all students pursuing the course (at the teacher’s request). The final decision to reschedule an examination is made by the dean of the faculty where the students are enrolled.11

footnotes: 11 Decisions to reschedule an examination for an inter-campus course (e.g., Minors, MAGOLEGO, and open optional courses) are made by an officer duly authorised by the HSE Rector in accordance with the established procedure.

text: 28. Any12 assessment element, including examinations, may be a blocking assessment and thus have a blocking effect. If an element blocks off any portion of the interim grade, this must be specified in the section of the course syllabus where the grading system is described.

footnotes: 12 With the exception of assessment elements that are not eligible for retakes; such elements are outlined in Clause 18 herein.

text: 29. If a course includes blocking assessment elements scheduled more than 10 (ten) calendar days before the examination period, the given course syllabus must provide students with an opportunity to have one retake for each blocking element before the examination period. The procedure and timeframe for retakes should be outlined in the course syllabus. Any retakes of blocking assessments will be conducted using similar CMMs and technologies as applied during the initial attempt to pass the given assessment element.

30. If the weight of a particular assessment element in the interim assessment grade is 30% or more, the course syllabus must offer students who may have missed the assessment the option of taking a make-up assessment. The teacher is entitled to hold a retake of the given assessment element for students who passed it with an unsatisfactory grade. Clause 29 herein establishes the procedure and timeframe for make-up assessments.

31. Those assessment elements that are not deemed blocking elements with a weight of less than 30% are not subject to retake by default, unless the teacher has provided this option in the syllabus. The teacher is entitled to hold a retake for students who missed an assessment element, regardless of a given student’s reason for missing the element, or a retake of an assessment element with a weights of less than 30% passed by the student with an unsatisfactory grade at the student's request.13

footnotes: 13 As a rule, such examinations and retakes, based on the teacher’s decision at the requests of individual students, are organised during the teacher’s consultations.

text: 32. If the formula (rule) for grade calculation does not allow for pinpointing the weight of a specific assessment element in the interim assessment grade (e.g., ranking of student assessment results in line with certain rules, minimum and maximum point values from several grades, selection from among several grades using a certain criterion, etc.), students who have missed such assessment elements must be provided with the option of sitting a make-up assessment for this element.14

footnotes: 14 With the exception of assessment elements that are not eligible for retakes; such elements are outlined in Clause 18 herein.

text: 33. If a course includes blocking assessment elements that are not examinations and are scheduled less than 10 (ten) calendar days before the examination period, retakes for these elements must take place before the end of the upcoming examination period. The interim assessment grade will only be calculated after retakes of such assessment elements are held. The retake procedure should be described in the course syllabus. Retakes of blocking assessment elements will be conducted using the same CMMs and technologies employed during the initial testing under this particular assessment element. Any potential conflicts between retakes and the established examination timetable will be resolved in accordance with Clause 67 herein.

34. An unsatisfactory grade received by a student for an assessment element in a course cannot serve as the grounds for their exclusion from further assessment elements (e.g., examinations) under the given course, held before the end of the oncoming examination period, which should include an interim assessment for the course.

35. Teachers are entitled to make minor adjustments to the number and procedures for assessment elements. In such instances, they must document such adjustments in the course syllabus using the Syllabus Builder and then inform students of any changes and the reasons behind them no later than 3 (three) academic days before the start of the adjusted assessment element (excluding examinations). Students, in turn, are entitled to notify their degree programmes’ academic supervisors about such changes within 3 (three) academic days after receiving the relevant information. The academic supervisor will make the final decision regarding the implementation of such changes. If the academic supervisor objects to the proposed changes, they will inform the relevant teacher via corporate email.

. If the academic supervisor objects to the proposed changes, they will inform the relevant teacher via corporate email. Additionally, teachers will inform students of any minor changes in examination procedures scheduled to take place during the examination period at the final class of the course before the start of the examination period or, in cases of asynchronous instruction, at least 5 (five) academic days before the examination period begins, and in writing. This information should be disseminated via the EIOS.

36. The assignment of blocking status to an assessment element and/or the transformation of the formula of weighted totals for calculating an interim grade into a non-linear expression, as well as any adjustments in the proctoring terms and conditions, stated in the syllabus,  may not be considered as minor adjustments and must be approved15 by the Student Council of the faculty overseeing the implementation of the degree programme, or by the HSE University Student Council if the proposed changes affect a course offered to students from multiple faculties/campuses. If approval is not obtained from the Student Council at either the faculty or University level, but significant changes are necessary to prevent a critical situation in the process of mastering the course, the authorised official duly empowered by the HSE Rector in accordance with the established procedure set forth in these Regulations may make the relevant decision.

footnotes: 15 The approval procedure is as follows: initiators of significant changes submit a substantiated description of their reasons for making the changes and a list of proposed changes by corporate email to the chairperson of the relevant Student Council, with a copy to the academic supervisor (if applicable). The Student Council then reviews the email within 2 (two) working days and sends a response with their approval or rejection of the changes to the initiator and the academic supervisor (if applicable).

text: 37. When planning an assessment element, subdivisions/faculties can develop and approve requirements16 for organising the assessment elements for a given course that teachers of the relevant subdivision/faculty must follow. The requirements shall be published on the website of the subdivision/faculty on the HSE University website (portal).

footnotes: 16 Requirements may describe recommended or mandatory methods for verifying a student's identity, as well as the use of proctoring and methods of monitoring the completion of assignments by students, etc.

text:
39. In regards to synchronous assessment elements with the grade taken into account in the overall interim assessment grade in accordance with the syllabus, students should be informed about the assessment element date:
39.1. for assessment elements held during classes prior to the examination period, the teacher must inform the students at least 1 (one) academic day before the assessment element date provided in the syllabus or via the EIOS;

39. In regards to synchronous assessment elements with the grade taken into account in the overall interim assessment grade in accordance with the syllabus, students should be informed about the assessment element date:
39.2. for assessment elements held during the examination period, the programme manager must inform the students within at least 7 (seven) calendar days via the electronic timetable.

40. The teacher is entitled to set an individual start time for a synchronous assessment element for each student (several students). In this case, the teacher must inform the student (several students) via the EIOS about their individual time within at least 1 (one) academic day before the date of the assessment element.

41. Materials provided by teachers to students for mastering a given course (videos of classes, lecture notes, additional printed materials, etc.), as well as other materials (e.g., audio and video materials) generated by students and teachers during online classes may be shared via the EIOS at the teacher’s discretion, in accordance with the procedures established by University bylaws. However, such materials should remain within the respective study group (cohort) and not be distributed through other channels.

42. During the assessment process, in accordance with a teacher’s decision, students may use the syllabus, reference books, and other sources, including generative models, selected by the teacher and listed in the given course syllabus.

books, and other sources, including generative models, selected by the teacher and listed in the given course syllabus. The use of materials not included in a specified list or, which is expressly prohibited, as well as any attempts to communicate with fellow students or others (e.g., via electronic communication), unauthorised movements, students' use of electronic communication tools despite explicit teacher restrictions, intentional disconnection from a video conference, or switching between browser tabs contrary to a teacher's explicit instructions, along with any other violations of the specified procedures for assessing students' knowledge and skills, shall serve as grounds for the termination of the assessment for those students found to be in violation of the respective rules (including their removal from the given classroom or video conference, etc.), and the assignment of a "0" grade for the given assessment element.

43. Students are required to attend the scheduled assessment at the designated time as outlined in the timetable or specified by their teacher. For remote assessment elements, students must join the video conference, upload files to the EIOS, complete the test, or access the assessment by any other means specified by the teacher at the precise time indicated in the timetable or specified by the teacher (for synchronous assessments). If a student is late, the teacher may extend the allotted time for the assessment element at their discretion.

44. The procedures for conducting remote assessment elements, including proctored assessments and user identification of students, will be detailed in the course syllabus and additionally communicated to students at least 1 (one) calendar day before the assessment's scheduled date.

45. Annex 1 hereto stipulates the relevant procedures that HSE University students, teachers, and staff should follow if technical issues prevent students from signing into the assessment system or starting the assessment, or technical issues arise during remote assessments featuring the use of proctoring technologies.

46. If a student, citing health reasons, decides not to participate in an assessment after arriving at the assessment location,17 they must declare this before receiving the assignment. In such cases, the student will be marked by the teacher as "absent" in the assessment record. For asynchronous assessment elements, students must notify their programme offices and teachers of their inability to complete the assignment due to health reasons before the submission deadline.
If a student chooses to discontinue their involvement in the assessment after completing only part of the given assignment, the completed portion will be assessed according to the established criteria.
If a student, after receiving an assignment from the teacher, declines to continue performing it, and has not completed any part of the assignment, a grade of "0" will be recorded in the ongoing assessment record.

footnotes: 17 Including by signing in to a video conference

text: 47. Students who are absent from an assessment element will have their absence noted as "absent" on the ongoing assessment record. Teachers are not permitted to mark students as "absent" at their request if the student was present at a class/examination (attended a video conference, submitted completed assignments, etc.) and had already commenced performance of the assigned task. A student’s absence from an assessment element other than an examination shall not be analysed by teachers and/or administrative staff at HSE University for the existence of valid reason for their absence.

48. A valid excuse for a student’s absence from an examination is deemed to be illness, as confirmed by a relevant medical certificate.18 Reasons stemming from a student’s employment, such as business trips or work schedules, are not deemed to be valid excuses for missing an examination. However, other excuses stemming from family or personal circumstances may be deemed valid in accordance with the procedure stipulated in these Regulations.

footnotes: 18 A medical certificate for the purposes of these Regulations is a certificate concerning a student’s temporary disability during a certain period, issued in the form and as per the established procedure approved by the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation. The University shall be entitled to verify the authenticity of medical certificates by sending a request to the medical institution that issued the certificate submitted by a student. In addition to said certificate, foreign students may provide information and documents issued by foreign organisations. Documents that are issued in languages other than Russian or English by foreign organisations, or received from foreign institutions, must be submitted together with an accompanying notarised translation into Russian or English.

text: 49. If a student misses an examination for a valid reason, they shall be entitled to file a formal application requesting that the specific reason for the given absence from the examination be validated/deemed valid within 5 (five) academic days after the date of the missed examination or no later than 5 (five) academic days after the date of the student’s recovery (if such date, in accordance with the respective medical certificate, is more than 5 (five) academic days after the examination date).

50. Such an application, specified in Clause 49 herein, is filed online via the student's personal account and must contain relevant information and documents confirming the validity of the reason for the absence.

51. The decision on whether to accept an application, as specified in Clause 49 herein, and whether to take it into consideration is made by the authorised staff member in charge of processing applications received via the student’s personal account (hereinafter, the “authorised staff member”). The authorised staff member may reject an application if it is not accompanied by documentary evidence of the stated valid reason for the student’s absence, as well as if the student failed to meet the established deadline for filing the application. If an application is rejected, the student shall be informed of the reasons for the rejection decision via their personal account. A grade of "0" will be assigned for a missed examination (including a retake).

tion decision via their personal account. A grade of "0" will be assigned for a missed examination (including a retake). When accepting an application to validate a student’s reason for their absence from an examination due to illness, the authorised staff member must inform the relevant programme manager (via the EIOS) about the given student’s stated valid reason for their absence from the examination. When accepting an application to validate a student’s reason for their absence that cites a reason other than illness, the authorised staff member shall defer to the relevant programme manager, who will then decide whether to validate the student’s stated reason for being absent from the examination. The programme manager will input the resulting decision in the UIS and inform the student via their personal account. If the application is rejected, the student will be informed of the reasons via their personal account.
ersonal account. If the application is rejected, the student will be informed of the reasons via their personal account. A grade of "0" will be assigned for a missed examination (including a retake).
52. Assessment results can be evaluated by teachers, teaching assistants, or automatically by using auto-grading tools on the EIOS.

53. Teachers are required to inform students about their grades no later than 10 calendar days following the date of the assessment that preceded the examination period. If an assessment takes place during the examination period, the results must be announced within 5 (five) working days following the conclusion of this period. Students will be notified via the EIOS.

54. During their mandatory office hours, teachers must offer individual or group consultations to students seeking additional feedback on their ongoing assessment results. For courses conducted asynchronously, a 60-minute consultation session must be available at least once for every 6 (six) hours of the course. Consultations can be conducted either with students and the teacher present in an HSE University classroom or using remote technologies (e.g., broadcasting, video conferencing, instant messaging via chat platforms, etc.). Teachers are required to provide students with details about the specific communication channel for consultations by specifying it in the EIOS, the course webpage, and/or their personal webpage on the HSE University corporate website (portal), and the class timetable.

55. If a course syllabus includes an examination, the teacher may exempt certain students from the examination if there are no doubts about their performance. Instead, during the examination period, these students will be assigned an interim assessment grade equivalent to their cumulative grade, excluding the weight of the examination (i.e., the total weights of all assessment elements without the examination will be considered equal to one19). If applicable, this option will be indicated in the course syllabus. The teacher must announce their decision no later than the last class of the course before the examination period. Grades will be communicated through the EIOS. Students have the option to decline receiving their grades without taking the examination and opt to take the examination instead, provided they inform the teacher no later than during the last class of the course.

footnotes: 19 The following formula can be used for assigning grades for the interim assessment: 0.2 Gtest + 0.3 Ghomework + 0.3 Gcolloquium + 0.2Gexam. The following formula can be used if the teacher is ready to give the student a grade weighted by 0.2 without an examination: 0.2/0.8 Gtest + 0.3/0.8 Ghomework + 0.3/0.8 Gcolloquium = 0.25 Gtest + 0.375 Ghomework + 0.375 Gcolloquium.

text:
56. Assessments involving blocking elements, including examinations, may be conducted with audio or video recording in accordance with the HSE University bylaws governing class video recordings, in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the appeals procedures, under the following conditions:
56.1. upon request from students or teachers: if classes in the given course are held in a face-to-face format. Requests for audio or video recordings should be submitted to the programme office no later than 4 (four) working days before the assessment element. The person who initiated the request will coordinate technical support for audio or video recording with the assistance of the programme office.

56. Assessments involving blocking elements, including examinations, may be conducted with audio or video recording in accordance with the HSE University bylaws governing class video recordings, in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the appeals procedures, under the following conditions:
56.2. on a mandatory basis: if classes are conducted remotely or in a blended learning format, recordings of oral assessment elements will be made by the teacher, assistant, or proctor.
57. The files will be handed over to the programme office of the student’s degree programme within 2 (two) working days.

58. Upon requests from the Appeals Committee, deans, vice rectors, the Rector, and/or members of the Academic Dispute Settlement Commission, the programme office of the degree programme will provide the files containing audio or video recordings within 1 (one) working day.

59. Interim assessment results will be tallied during the examination period. To maintain the integrity of teaching quality assessments submitted by students, in accordance with HSE University regulations, interim or final grades for a course cannot be assigned before the examination period.

text: 68. To register interim results, each teacher must access the online interim assessment record sheet in the EIOS. This sheet should include the course title, a list of students admitted to the interim assessment, and a reference number. If an examiner does not have access to the EIOS, the programme office may send interim assessment records electronically via email upon request.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 69. Students not listed in the online interim assessment record generated by the relevant programme office will not be assigned a grade. Grades awarded to students who are not included in the online interim assessment record drawn up by the programme office will be cancelled by decision of the faculty dean once the discrepancy is identified.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 70. If a given course includes an examination, upon its completion, or after checking the written examination papers, the examiner will calculate the interim grade for the course based on the formula (rule) outlined in the course syllabus. This grade will then be entered into the interim assessment record. If the examination was conducted verbally, the examiner may announce the grade immediately after the student's response, provided that no additional time is required for grade calculation.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 71. If a student is absent during the examination, the examiner must calculate and register the interim grade resulting in a grade of "0"  in the interim assessment record in accordance with the formula (rule) provided in the course syllabus, marking the student as absent in the designated column of the record.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 72. A positive grade for an interim assessment assigned to a student who missed an examination may be revised if their absence was for a valid reason duly confirmed by documentary evidence (as outlined in Clauses 48-51 herein) and if the student participates in a make-up examination, in accordance with Section VIII of these Regulations. In such cases, the degree programme manager will update the grade in the UIS based on the assessment record sheet.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 73. If a course concludes with an examination held before the official examination period, the teacher will calculate the interim grade, relying on the formula (rule) specified in the respective course syllabus, no earlier than the starting date and no later than the final date of the nearest examination period.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 74. The interim grade for a given course will be registered in the online interim assessment record using a 10-point grading scale. A special EIOS service will automatically translate these point values into a qualitative description on a five-point grading scale (e.g., “(8) Excellent,” “(6) Good,” etc.).
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 75. The lead teacher will ensure that assessment records are completed accurately and submitted on time by all teachers involved in implementing the given course.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 76. Assessment records must be certified with the electronic signature of the examiner, or the board of examiners, using the designated EIOS service. In cases where a course is taught by multiple teachers, they must reach a preliminary agreement on the content of the assessment record via the EIOS before a final document may be signed by one teacher.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 77. Completed interim assessment records must be submitted via the EIOS to the programme office within 5 (five) working days after the end of the examination period. If an examiner cannot access the EIOS service for signing assessment records, a scanned copy signed by the examiner may be forwarded to the programme office manager via corporate email. If the record sheet was submitted to the programme office electronically, the original copy must be retained and archived by the subdivision.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 78. The programme manager will sign the assessment record sheet using the EIOS. If the assessment record was submitted as a scanned copy, the programme manager will register the grades in the special EIOS module.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 79. Within 3 (three) working days after determining the interim assessment grades, the teacher will send students a file containing grade calculations, which must feature all grades across the assessment elements specified in the course syllabus, via the course webpage in the EIOS.
heading_path: IV. Examination Periods and Interim Assessment Results

text: 80. If any errors are identified by a student or degree programme manager in the grade calculation, they must contact the teacher within 5 (five) working days of receiving access to the grade calculation file. In turn, within 2 (two) working days of receipt of the relevant inquiry, the teacher will, if they concur with the identified errors, make the necessary corrections and notify both the degree programme manager and lead teacher of the respective amendments in the record sheet. The degree programme manager will assist the teacher in making any required adjustments to the assessment record. If the teacher does not concur with the concerns raised, however, they must provide an explanation of their position to the student or degree programme manager within 2 (two) working days. Should the student remain dissatisfied with the teacher's response, they may escalate the matter to the academic supervisor within 2 (two) working days.

3. Optional Course in Academic Writing in English and 
Project Proposal Defence on the Thesis Topic in English

text: 105. Final-year students enrolled in Bachelor’s and Specialist degree programmes may have the option to enrol in an elective course in Academic Writing in English, known as the Academic Writing Course. This course is aimed at enhancing students' abilities to work with English-language sources while drafting their theses. It is also aimed at systematising the knowledge and skills required to prepare and deliver presentations of academic, project-based, and research texts in English. Students are not required to undergo an examination in Academic Writing. The syllabus for the Academic Writing Course should be developed by the subdivision responsible for delivering the course. Upon successful completion of the Academic Writing Course, students are expected to draft a detailed plan of their thesis in English (hereinafter, the “Project Proposal”).
heading_path:
V. Special Aspects of Assessments and Examinations 
under Certain Courses and Course Elements

text: Course, students are expected to draft a detailed plan of their thesis in English (hereinafter, the “Project Proposal”). The Project Proposal is an essential component of a student's thesis in accordance with the educational standards of the respective Bachelor’s and Specialist degree programmes at HSE University.
heading_path:
V. Special Aspects of Assessments and Examinations 
under Certain Courses and Course Elements

text: 106. The Academic Writing Course is optional, and students have the choice to exclude this course from their individual curriculum. If students opt out of this course, they are expected to develop their Project Proposals independently.

text: 107. A student's Project Proposal will be scrutinised for unauthorised citations according to the established procedure27 at HSE University and within the timeframe set by the academic supervisor of the degree programme.

text: 108. Regardless of whether or not the Academic Writing Course is included in a student's individual curriculum, they are required to deliver a public presentation of their Project Proposal before an academic board (hereinafter, the “Project Proposal Defence”). The procedure28 for the Project Proposal Defence and the composition of the board will be determined by the academic supervisor of the degree programme in accordance with the internship programme, which is individually approved for each degree programme or group of degree programmes within faculties. Students from different degree programmes may be called upon to defend their Project Proposals simultaneously.

text: 109. It is recommended that the Project Proposal Defence be scheduled during the Module 3 examination period. The defence should take place no later than 2 (two) weeks after the conclusion of Module 3 in the student's final year of study.

text: 122. Students enjoy the right to appeal the results of those assessment elements that are specified in a course syllabus as blocking assessments and/or examinations (including retakes), with the exception of those cases where a student receives a grade of 8 or higher for the aforementioned assessment elements.

123. Students may file appeals to the academic supervisor of the relevant degree programme within 3 (three) working days from the date when grades for a given blocking assessment and/or examination (including retakes) were announced.

124. An appeal must specify the grounds for filing the given appeal. Such grounds may include the following:
124.1. assessments failing to meet the criteria established in the course syllabus;

124. An appeal must specify the grounds for filing the given appeal. Such grounds may include the following:
124.2. mistakes in the wording of tasks and exam assignments made on the part of their authors;

124. An appeal must specify the grounds for filing the given appeal. Such grounds may include the following:
124.3. procedural irregularities in the University’s established process for conducting assessment elements on the part of the examiner;

124. An appeal must specify the grounds for filing the given appeal. Such grounds may include the following:
124.4. other circumstances that prevent an examiner from assessing the work objectively.
125. A student’s dissatisfaction with their grade will not suffice as grounds for filing an appeal.
126. The outcomes of the second retake of the examination shall be subject to appeal only on the grounds provided for in Sub-Clause 124.3, Clause 124 of the Regulations.

127. The student may submit an application submitted on the basis provided for in Sub-Clause 124.1, Clause 124 of the Regulations with a request to review the grades for all or some components of the assessment element. In this case, the student should specify what amount of points should be awarded for all or some components of the assessment element.
128. Mistakes committed in assignments should be listed in the relevant appeal application submitted by the student on the grounds provided for in Sub-Clause 124.2, Clause 124 of the Regulations.

129. The student must provide evidence confirming the specific circumstances described in the appeal application submitted on the grounds provided for in Sub-Clauses 124.3 and 124.4 of Clause 124 herein. Suspicions, speculation, hearsay, or conjecture shall not be deemed suitable as evidence.

130. The academic supervisor retains the right to refuse to review an appeal if there are no grounds for it. Such a decision to reject an appeal should be substantiated and communicated to the student via the EIOS.

131. Appeals will be addressed within 3 (three) working days by a designated Appeals Committee, comprising at least 3 (three) teachers, with one appointed as chairperson. The examiner responsible for the blocking assessment or any retake thereof is ineligible to sit on the Appeals Committee.

132. The composition of the Appeals Committee, including its chairperson and secretary,31 and the scheduled meeting date will be formalised through a written resolution by the head of the subdivision responsible for delivering the given course. The Appeals Committee may include teachers from other subdivisions. The subdivision head must coordinate the meeting time with all members and the examiner who administered the pertinent blocking assessment element.

footnotes: 31 The secretary will not sit on the Appeals Committee.

text: 133. Participants in Appeals Committee meetings shall be notified by the Appeals Committee secretary within at least 24 hours before a meeting is convened.

134. The Appeals Committee will convene its session with the student and examiner32 who administered the blocking element and/or examination or retake thereof present. Additionally, a representative from the Student Council of the faculty where the student is enrolled/HSE University Student Council (if no such faculty Student Council exists)/the Student Council of the relevant HSE University regional campus (for students at regional campuses) may attend the meeting, subject to prior approval from the Appeals Committee’s chairperson. However, the representative of the HSE University (faculty/regional campus) Student Council shall not be considered a member of the Appeals Committee. By decision of the Appeals Committee’s chairperson, audio or video recording of the meeting may be arranged, in accordance with the procedure outlined in Sub-Clause 56.1, Clause 56 herein.

footnotes: 32 If the blocking element was overseen by the board, the board’s chairperson will attend the meeting.

text: 135. Should the chairperson of the Appeals Committee so decide, either all or select members of the committee may participate in its meetings online, alongside other invited individuals. The timing, format, and venue (platform) of the meeting must be conveyed to the student and the examiner responsible for the blocking assessment element and/or examination or retake thereof at least 24 hours before the meeting, using any available means. If the Appeals Committee convenes online, the secretary will arrange a video conference. It is the responsibility of the programme office to inform both the student and the teacher about the details of the meeting and to document the precise time and method of transmitting this information.

136. Failure to attend the Appeals Committee meeting (including an online session) by the student and/or the examiner, who administered the blocking assessment element and/or examination or retake thereof, even after proper notification of the meeting time and venue, will not hinder a review of the appeal.

137. The Appeals Committee will consider only the claims (grounds) outlined in the student’s appeal. Additionally, the committee’s decisions may be supported by audio or video recordings (if available) of the blocking assessment and/or the examination, or any retake thereof. Further questioning of the student regarding their work or the course materials is not permitted. Moreover, all persons other than the Appeals Committee members and secretary must vacate the meeting venue (platform) or be removed from the video conference by the committee’s secretary when the committee members begin deliberating on the case to reach their final verdict.

138. The Appeals Committee may resolve to recess during its review of the appeal if such a recess is deemed necessary for a full and comprehensive study of the paper. In this case, the time, format, and venue (platform) of the meeting after such a recess shall be determined by the chairperson of the Appeals Committee and communicated to the participants present at the meeting. Furthermore, those persons who were invited to the meeting of the Appeals Committee but were absent during the consideration of the appeal will not be additionally informed that the review process has been resumed.
139. The Appeals Committee will either uphold or reject the appeal, thereby confirming or negating the presence of a violation, respectively.

140. If the appeal is upheld, except in those cases stipulated in Clause 141 herein, the results of the blocking assessment or its retake will be voided. Consequently, the student may undergo a make-up assessment or retake within the timeframe outlined by the degree programme manager, but no later than 1 (one) month after the Appeals Committee meeting.

141. If the student contests the results of a written blocking assessment element or its retake, and if the nature of the written assignments and responses allows the Appeals Committee to assign a new grade without a retake, no make-up assessment for the blocking element will be required. The Appeals Committee evaluates the paper in accordance with the criteria provided for in the syllabus. The Appeals Committee is entitled to award a lower grade if it is decided that the previous grade did not correspond to the contents of the paper or contradicts the assessment requirements set forth in the syllabus. The new grade will be documented in the Appeals Committee minutes and signed by the chairperson of the Appeals Committee. The Appeals Committee will determine whether the student can receive a new grade without undergoing a make-up examination by a simple majority vote; in the event of a tie, the Appeals Committee chairperson will cast the deciding vote.
142. If the appeal is rejected, the result of the blocking assessment element examination or the retake outcomes shall remain unchanged.

143. The final decision of the Appeals Committee will be documented in the minutes signed by the chairperson. A substantiated explanation of the decision shall be provided in the minutes. The form of the minutes shall be drawn up by the Degree Programmes Office and published on the HSE University website (portal) on the HSE Academic Handbook page.

144. The signed minutes shall be submitted to the respective degree programme office no later than the next working day for the execution of the Appeals Committee’s decision. If the meeting of the Appeals Committee is held online, the final minutes shall be signed by the chairperson and sent to the persons responsible for the implementation of the decision in the form of an electronic copy using the EIOS.

145. The decision of the Appeals Committee shall be communicated to students by the degree programme manager.

VII. Student Performance Assessment and Terms for 
Continuing Studies with Outstanding Academic Failures

146. Following the examination periods and retake periods outlined in the academic calendar and the degree programme’s curriculum, every student undergoes evaluation as part of the Student Performance Assessment (hereinafter, the “SPA”). Based on the SPA results, decisions are made as to whether or not a student can continue their studies under the same conditions.

147. The determination of an SPA is the responsibility of the degree programme manager after each examination period and retake period for each student in the degree programme. The SPA has a critical threshold. For students not falling under special categories, the critical SPA value is 2 (two) (hereinafter, a “regular SPA”). If a student's SPA exceeds the regular SPA for the first time, the critical value for students in special categories is set at 5 (five). Subsequent assessments for students in special categories will use the regular SPA to determine the conditions for continuing their studies.

148. Within 10 (ten) working days after each examination period or period of retakes, the degree programme manager calculates the SPA, taking into considering unsatisfactory grades and/or unexplained absences during interim assessments, independent examinations, and external assessments. UIS tools and data are used to complete the calculations. Before making the calculations, the degree programme manager must ensure the completeness and accuracy of student grade information, as well as absences and valid reasons therefor.
Up to five instances of academic failure, received for the first time by a student who comes under a specific category outlined in these Regulations, will be deemed acceptable and the reasons for them deemed valid, in connection with which the programme manager will not record them as the given student’s failure to properly master the degree programme, in accordance with the established procedure set forth in these Regulations.

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.1. two unsatisfactory grades for interim assessments within the same course during 2 (two) examination periods, between the retake periods, are considered as 1 (one) unsatisfactory grade;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.2. an unsatisfactory grade for an interim assessment in a course included in the student’s individual curriculum (IC), but chosen additionally beyond the standard study load offered in the curriculum, including optional courses, is considered alongside other unsatisfactory grades;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.3. an unsatisfactory grade for an open optional course does not contribute to the total count of unsatisfactory grades;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.4. absence from a mandatory external examination is treated as a separate component in the SPA calculation;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.5. the number of unsatisfactory grades for independent examinations is determined according to Clauses 93, 94, and 102 herein;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.6. unsatisfactory grades received by the student during their first attempt at a course that is transferred to the second retake in accordance with the procedure established in these Regulations, and the course must be repeated by the student, are not included in the SPA;

149. The SPA is determined according to specific rules, taking into consideration the special features of courses, independent examinations, and external assessments:
149.7. unsatisfactory grades for courses received by the student during previous retakes or independent examinations, improved in accordance with the procedure established in these Regulations or received before, but not liquidated by the time of the SPA calculation, are counted according to the same rules as other unsatisfactory grades specified in the present clause as well as Clause 147 herein.

150. If a student's SPA surpasses critical values, taking into account their status in a special student category and the repeated occurrence or absence of critical situations, the degree programme manager will consider additional criteria to evaluate the student's diligence in mastering the degree programme and adhering to the curriculum, as outlined in Clause 9 herein.

151. A student’s failure to meet their obligations to diligently pursue the degree programme and follow the curriculum, as stipulated in Clause 9 herein, may result in the student's dismissal from HSE University, in accordance with Clause 2, Part 2, Article 61 of Federal Law No. 273-FZ "On Education in the Russian Federation," dated December 29, 2012.

152. The degree programme manager will compile a list of students whose SPA exceeds the critical values, along with any additional information indicating their failure to adequately master the degree programme. This list will be sent to the academic supervisor of the degree programme for drawing up relevant documents, who will then determine the subsequent course of action in accordance with the procedures outlined in the University's bylaws.

153. The degree programme manager will notify students through the EIOS if their SPA meets the established criteria but they fail to attain satisfactory grades for interim assessments, or attend external examinations, prompting them to rectify their academic failures.

154. Students who have not selected a topic and a supervisor for mandatory PTE, including their thesis, within the stipulated timeframe, will be assigned a topic and a supervisor within 10 (ten) working days after the end of the stipulated timeframe. The academic supervisor of the degree programme will select a free topic/place in the PTE/ PTE supervisor from among those previously agreed upon by the academic supervisor and the subdivision head and offered to students in accordance with the established procedure. In the absence of free topics/places in the PTE with a specific PTE supervisor, previously agreed upon, the academic supervisor shall determine and approve a topic/place in the PTE/PTE supervisor with the head of the relevant subdivision participating in degree programme implementation. The results are recorded in the UIS by the degree programme manager and communicated to the student through the EIOS.

155. Information regarding interim assessment grades, including details of academic failures and SPA indicators, will be accessible to students via their personal account on the EIOS.

VIII. Rectifying Academic Failures
156. Academic failures shall be rectified through participating in specially arranged retake sessions.

157. Retaking an interim assessment to improve a satisfactory grade (i.e., four points or higher on a 10-point scale) is generally not permitted, except in those cases outlined in Clauses 72, 102, and 112 herein.

158. Students are allowed to retake interim assessments for the same course within 1 (one) academic year from the date of the initial failure, excluding periods during which the given student is absent for health reasons, exceptional leave, or maternity leave.
159. An audio and/or video recording of the retake can be arranged in accordance with the procedure stipulated in Clause 56 herein.

160. The initial retake of interim assessments (hereinafter, the "first retake") for a specific course, which includes blocking assessment elements and does not involve an examination during the examination period or within 10 (ten) calendar days prior to it, will be organised as a combination of retakes of individual blocking elements and held before the examination period. Otherwise, the first retake will occur during the retake period.

161. The first retake during the retake period will be administered by the same examiner who conducted the initial interim examination (hereinafter, the "initial examiner"). Another teacher may administer the first retake only if agreed upon by the lead teacher (or the subdivision head if the lead teacher is unavailable) and the initial examiner. If the initial examiner is no longer employed at HSE University or is unable to oversee the retake for other reasons, the lead teacher (or the subdivision head) will designate another examiner to conduct the first retake.

162. The procedure for the first retake must adhere to the same standards as the initial examination, although adjustments to the format may be made if outlined in the course syllabus. For instance, different technologies and formats can be used for first retakes, such as proctoring or testing platforms. Retakes of assessments, including face-to-face examinations, can be conducted remotely. Only the unsatisfactory grade received at the examination may be revised, and thus previous assessment grades for other assessment elements will remain unchanged.

163. If a course includes assessment elements that cannot be retaken, a grade of "0" is assigned for those elements of the interim assessment if the student did not previously receive any grades for them.

164. The first retake for a course without blocking assessment elements and the examination will be based on CMMs specially designed for retakes by the lead teacher. Such CMMs must enable examiners to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the student's academic progress based on assessment elements that can be retaken. The examination technology using CMMs for retakes will be outlined in the course syllabus. If the syllabus provides for assessment elements that cannot be repeated, then the grade for the interim assessment received by the student under the SPA for retakes will be counted in the grade calculation with the total weight (according to the applicable rules) provided for those parts of the assessment that could be repeated. Grades for assessment elements that cannot be repeated are not subject to change.

165. The second retake of interim assessment results (hereinafter, the "second retake") may be conducted remotely and will be overseen by a special examination board comprising a minimum of 3 (three) examiners.

166. Only unsatisfactory grades received after the first retake for courses with an examination shall be subject to a second retake. The cumulative grade for other assessment elements shall remain unchanged.

167. For courses without an examination, unsatisfactory grades received at the first retake under the SPA for retakes shall be subject to a retake. Grades for assessment elements that cannot be repeated are not subject to retakes.

168. The date of the second retake, as well as the composition of the board membership and the name of the chairperson of the board, will be specified in a written resolution issued by the head of the relevant subdivision responsible for the course. The board must include the initial examiner and at least 2 (two) other teachers with at least 1 (one) of them not involved in teaching the course to the student retaking the assessment. Teachers from other subdivisions may also be designated as board members. The examiner may not be appointed as the chairperson of the board.

169. Relevant CMMs for the second retake of any type of course will be developed under the supervision of the board chairperson. The technology for conducting assessments using these CMMs for the second retake will be specified in the course syllabus. The CMMs for the second retake may differ from those used for the first retake or be the same with respect to the selection of learning outcomes to be assessed, as well as assessment technologies.

170. The second retake of an oral examination will be conducted in the presence of at least 3 (three) board members, including the chairperson. All or some of the board members may participate online if necessary, and a video conference can be arranged by the board chairperson, or by a subdivision manager at the chairperson’s request. Grades will be assigned upon completion of the board meeting.

171. The second retake of a written examination requires completion of the written assignment in the presence (e.g., online presence) of at least 1 (one) board member. All board members must read and evaluate the written papers, including on an individual basis. Grades assigned for written assignments must be submitted to the chairperson. Grades must be assigned within 5 (five) working days after the retake date, but no later than the last day of the retake period.

172. The grade for a second retake will be determined by consensus among the board members. In case of any discrepancies in grades, the final grade will be decided by a simple majority vote. If a tie occurs, the grade assigned by the board chairperson will take precedence.

173. The results of the second retake will be documented in the minutes of the meeting, which must be signed by all board members. For oral examinations, the minutes will include the examination questions and a brief summary of the student's answers. For written examinations, the minutes will contain the examination questions and a brief evaluation of the answers provided. If the retake was conducted online, a copy of the signed minutes will be sent to the student’s programme office via the EIOS.

174. The retake schedule for full-time degree students will be approved twice per year by the degree programme manager. The retake period for full-time students cannot commence before the conclusion of the examination periods for Modules 2 and 4.

175. The number, start date, and end date of retake periods for students enrolled in degree programmes with a non-standard academic calendar, approved in accordance with the established procedure, will be determined by a directive issued by the dean of the faculty offering the programme. The retake timetable for such students must be approved for each retake period by the respective degree programme manager.

176. Retake sessions cannot be scheduled to take place during vacation periods.
The retake periods for full-time degree students must conclude by the following dates:

Academic failure in: | Deadline for retake periods
Modules 3–4 | October 15
Modules 1–2 | February 15
177. Students in their final year of study will be granted an additional retake period for failed courses in Module 3 before the commencement of the Final State Certification.

178. The retake timetable, encompassing both the first and second retakes, will be prepared by the specific programme office or the Degree Programmes Office (for university-wide courses). Prior to scheduling the first retake, the responsible manager will consult with the examiner to determine the number of retake dates required, taking into consideration the number of students and the retake procedure.
179. There must be a minimum interval of 5 (five) calendar days between the first retake and the second retake administered by a board.

180. Students who failed examinations during the previous examination period will be notified of the retake timetable at least 3 (three) days before the first retake. Notifications will be sent to students via the EIOS.

181. In the event of a significant conflict between the retake timetable and the class schedule, students may submit a request via their personal account to explore potential options for rescheduling retakes within the established retake period.

182. Programme offices will schedule make-up examinations for students who missed an examination during the designated period for valid reasons on the first available retake date in the retake timetable. In case of unsatisfactory examination results, the first retake date will be scheduled on the second available date in the retake timetable or on the date of the second retake for other students.

183. Programme offices must maintain the records of those students registered for retakes. If the maximum number of participants set by a teacher for a specific date is exceeded, the affected students may be offered an alternative retake date by their programme office.
184. Retake dates should be mutually agreed upon by students and programme offices via the EIOS.

185. Retake record sheets must be prepared, transferred, and collected by the examiner or board chairperson following the procedures outlined in these Regulations for examination record sheets. Completed retake record sheets with final results should be submitted to the degree programme manager via the EIOS within 5 (five) calendar days after the retake and before the final date of the retake period, specified in Clause 176 herein.

186. If an examiner or student is unable to attend a retake for a valid reason, the student, the teacher, or the board chairperson must notify the University accordingly in compliance with the applicable procedures for examinations.

187. If a significant number of students33 are unable to attend the first or second retakes for valid reasons, the degree programme manager may decide to schedule additional retake dates within the retake timeframe specified in these Regulations.

footnotes: 33 Over 50% of students who failed examinations or missed them for a valid reason during the examination period.

text: 188. Upon the completion of the retake period, a student who has not used up the allotted number of retakes will be deemed to have failed to rectify their previously failed assessments.

189. If a student did not attend the first and/or second retake for a valid reason during the retake period, the dean of the relevant faculty shall assign new retake dates to the student within 10 (ten) calendar days after the retake period or shall assign them to the next retake period, provided that the provisions of Clause 158 herein are observed. If the period of the student’s academic failure exceeds 1 (one) calendar year (excluding days of absence for health reasons, an exceptional leave of absence or maternity leave), the University shall be entitled to initiate the student’s expulsion stemming from the given student’s failure to duly master the degree programme.

190. In exceptional cases, a retake may be scheduled prior to the retake period during the ongoing examination period. Such decisions may be made by the degree programme’s academic supervisor with the consent of the teacher who administered the examination. However, the total number of permissible retakes shall remain unchanged. Requests for early retakes addressed to the academic supervisor of a given degree programme must provide specific detailed reasons why the given case should be deemed exceptional and include supporting documentation confirming the student's circumstances.

191. It is the responsibility of students to inquire about their interim assessment results. A given student’s lack of awareness of their interim results shall not excuse them from their responsibilities and cannot be cited as a valid reason for missing retakes or failing to meet the deadlines for filing appeals.

192. After the first retake, students with one or two failed assignments shall have one of the following two options:
192.1. opt for the second retake within the ongoing retake period (hereinafter, the "standard option");

192. After the first retake, students with one or two failed assignments shall have one of the following two options:
192.2. choose not to participate in the second retake and instead request to repeat the course under the respective educational agreement on the specific degree programme component (hereinafter, a "repeated course").

193. The option of taking a repeated course may be provided for no more than 2 (two) courses, and only for those courses that, in accordance with the approved curricula, permit arranging a second retake within a period that is no more than 1 (one) calendar year from the first date of the academic failure (excluding days of illness).
194. However, if at least 1 (one) failed assignment remains unresolved after 3 (three) attempts, the student will face dismissal from the University for academic failure.

195. The conditions for granting a student's request to take a repeated course are as follows:
195.1. students funded by Russian federal budget subsidies may use this option but must transfer to a fee-paying place under an educational agreement;

195. The conditions for granting a student's request to take a repeated course are as follows:
195.2. students with HSE University-funded tuition (an HSE University target place) may take this option provided that the given student’s educational relations with the University continue after their tuition fees cease to be funded by HSE University;

195. The conditions for granting a student's request to take a repeated course are as follows:
195.3. students in special categories can take this option and continue their studies under the same financial terms and conditions only once during their entire study period at the University. In the second and subsequent instances, the procedure stipulated in Sub-Clauses 195.1 and 195.2 of this clause of the Regulation shall apply to such students.

196. If the student agrees to the conditions outlined in Clause 195 herein, they must submit an application through their online personal account within 2 (two) calendar days before the date of the second retake. The application shall be technically reviewed by authorised staff and the degree programme manager. If the requirements are met, the second retake will not be scheduled in the ongoing retake period. If an application is rejected, the student will be notified of the reasons via their personal account, and the dates for the second retakes will be promptly designated by the degree programme manager.

197. If the second retake date has been rescheduled and the option of a repeated course is approved, the student will retake the course or courses in which they have failed assignments under the educational agreement for the degree programme component. This process will be organised in accordance with the relevant bylaws governing the delivery of the educational programme component and the calculation of tuition fees in case of changes in the educational track.

198. After completing the repeated courses, students who have taken this option will undergo an examination before the examination board as a third and final attempt (the second retake) no later than during the retake period scheduled within 1 (one) calendar year after their first retake period.

199. If the student fails to rectify at least 1 (one) failed assignment after their third attempt (the second retake), they will be expelled from the University for failing to master the degree programme.

200. Students who successfully complete the academic year:
200.1. if their SPA equals zero, are eligible to progress to the next academic year in accordance with the established procedure;

200. Students who successfully complete the academic year:
200.2. if their SPA is greater than zero, but lower than the critical values, are eligible to progress to the next academic year on a provisional basis and may proceed to the following academic year provided that they rectify their academic failure at the beginning of the new academic year during the established retake period.

201. Similarly, students in their final year, upon completing all courses and interim assessments as part of their curriculum:
201.1. if their SPA equals zero, are eligible to take part in the Final State Certification at the University, in accordance with the established procedure;

201. Similarly, students in their final year, upon completing all courses and interim assessments as part of their curriculum:
201.2. if their SPA is greater than zero, but lower than the critical values, shall be entitled to opt to repeat34 a course without facing dismissal from the University, but only after the first retake organised during the additional retake period before the scheduled Final State Certification;

footnotes: 34 If a final-year student’s curriculum permits them to take a course in which they have an academic failure before the start of the Final State Certification process, then the given student may submit an application to the dean of the faculty with a substantiated request that they be allowed to take the examination ahead of schedule to the examination board before its completion within the timeframes established by Clause 177 herein.

text:
201. Similarly, students in their final year, upon completing all courses and interim assessments as part of their curriculum:
201.3. if their SPA exceeds the critical value, then the students shall be expelled from the University, in accordance with the established procedure.

202. During the assessment process, aside from examiners, assistant teachers, proctors, doctoral students, and teaching support staff assisting examiners with examinations, other university officials such as the HSE University Rector, vice rectors, faculty deans, academic supervisors of degree programmes, subdivision heads, and representatives of the Degree Programmes Office may attend. Any other individuals may attend only with the consent of the faculty dean.

203. Students may individually contest any violations of these Regulations that may have been committed by teachers and teaching support staff in subdivisions and programme offices by filing an appeal to the faculty dean or the authorised official duly empowered by the HSE Rector in accordance with the established procedure. Any failure to adhere to these Regulations by teaching and teaching support staff will be regarded as a violation of the established procedures for carrying out the study process.

204. A hard copy of these Regulations must be available at all programme offices and subdivisions, and an electronic version must be accessible on the webpages of degree programmes, departments, and faculties on the HSE University corporate website (portal). The relevant degree programme managers and subdivision heads shall be responsible for ensuring compliance with this requirement in terms of publishing these Regulations on the webpages of degree programmes, departments, and faculties.
205. Annex 6 hereto stipulates the procedures for interim and ongoing assessments for students with disabilities and special needs.
206. Annex 7 hereto stipulates the procedures for interim and ongoing assessments for students enrolled in the Bachelor’s programme "HSE/NES Programme in Economics" (Faculty of Economic Sciences).

207. Annex 8 hereto stipulates the procedures for interim and ongoing assessments of students enrolled in the degree programmes in the "Design" and "Fine Arts" fields of study, as well as the "Modern Technologies for Teaching Design and Art" degree programme in the "Pedagogical Education" field of study.
208. Annex 9 hereto stipulates the procedures for interim and ongoing assessments of students in the Master’s programme in "Math for Machine Learning" (Faculty of Computer Science).
